candidates.title: Remove memflow-win32
candidates.body: win32 OS layer has been moved to https://github.com/memflow/memflow-win32

candidates.title: Redesigned logging infrastructure for memflow plugins
candidates.body: This PR redesigns the logging infrastructure of memflow. Plugins now have a special logger instance which allows them to forward all logging calls over the FFI back to the main logger. This allows users to choose their own logging frontend and still allow plugins to use the user supplied logger.

candidates.title: Merge 0.2
candidates.body:
This PR merges the next branch into the main branch and contains all changes for version 0.2.0.
We should discuss the last necessary steps before we can finally merge and release 0.2.0 here.

- [x] CGlue 0.2
- [x] Restructure modules
- [ ] Update documentation
- [ ] memflow book (examples)
- [x] Move out memflow-win32
- [ ] Custom properties for plugins (connectors and os)
- [ ] Minor MMU changes (future proofing for RV64)

candidates.title: Refactoring all instances of u64/usize to the new umem/imem model
candidates.body: This PR replaces the currently hardcoded u64/usize values with a new umem/imem typedef. Additionally a new PrimitiveAddress trait is added which will allow writing generics that abstract over the targets address type (u32/u64 or later u128).

candidates.title: Unify memory frontend
candidates.body:
Simplify memflow usage for an end-user by having just one frontend for both physical and virtual memory reads.

Remove `VirtualMemory`, and replace it with `MemoryView`. All `virt_` funcs have no prefix, and for instance, `virt_read` becomes just `read`. This is because these functions also work on physical memory accesses, and other custom views.

Currently, there are just 3 primary traits an user would interact most with: `Os`, `Process`, `MemoryView`.

Optionally, there is `VirtualTranslate`, which is available only with DMA, and `PhysicalMemory`, which is the first thing available on DMA, but it is not meant to be used.

Did not auto-impl `MemoryView` on `PhysicalMemory`, because of conflicting implementations with CGlue. Instead, there are 2 functions - `phys_view`, and `into_phys_view` to create a `MemoryView` out of a `PhysicalMemory` object. I think this is good, because that allows an OS to have a default virtual memory view, and then optionally provide a secondary physical memory view. I believe physical memory lies kinda not in OS' control so it makes sense. A thing to note is that `CGlue` helper is not being generated for these functions - an alternative way to acquire phys mem view needs to be provided, perhaps through the FFI-lib.

`PhysicalMemory` was not removed, because it is the interface connectors implement. While it could be possible to fully merge the traits through associated types, I believe it is not worth it, because they have slight variations in them, and user experience might be a little confused.

`MemoryView` can be extended with structures that allow to build additional views on top of each other. Think isolating a slice of emulator memory, perhaps even re-mapping pages, and then performing reads inside the emulated address space. I think this change is also necessary for sane nested introspection.

Finally, there should be some efficiency improvements, because the core read/write data stream is an iterator, which would allow for streamed reads.

candidates.title: OS Layers
candidates.body:
This PR implements OS traits and dynamically loadable OS libraries.

There have been many changes throughout. Most notably, removal of some old traits, addition of more general traits and structures, renames of functions to be more general, removal of old interfaces.

Biggest breaking change: removal of `memflow-win32-ffi`. All previous functionality and more will be provided by `memflow-ffi`.
Another big change is removal of `memflow::process` module. It was replaced with a much simpler mechanism in the `memflow::os` module.

In memflow-win32, `Kernel`, `KernelBuilder`, and `KernelInfo` were renamed to `Win32Kernel`, `Win32KernelBuilder`, and `Win32KernelInfo`.

Added generic traits: `OSInner`, `OS`, `Process`.
`OS` provides all functionality that a generic OS would provide: access to processes, as well as optional features like keyboard input, physical/kernel virtual memory access. It does not limit itself to be based on DMA, and a `Kernel` could in theory be implemented as an abstraction for native OS APIs. Applications are endless, and include: clean nested introspection.
`OS` is a supertrait of `OSInner`. It is needed, because `OSInner` accepts lifetime `'a`, which can only be removed once GAT (Generic Associated Types) are available.
`Process` abstracts away a single process. It provides: virtual memory access, module list, basic process information.

Processes and modules are now described in a simple C compatible way: `ProcessInfo`, and `ModuleInfo` structs. They have all generic information that would be applicable to any process.

This PR merges the next branch into the main branch and contains all changes for version 0.2.0.
